Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Provenance and Thermal Evolution of the Chugach-Prince William Terrane Flysch, Southern Alaska
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chugach-Prince William terrane is an extensive accretionary complex that formed along the western margin of North America during subduction (under-thrusting) of oceanic lithosphere in the Cretaceous to Eocene. It was intruded by near-trench igneous rocks inferred to be related to the subduction of an oceanic ridge (where new ocean crust is formed), but the location of this terrane at the time of ridge interaction is under considerable debate. There are two prevailing hypotheses for its position at the time of formation: 1) The Chugach-Prince William terrane formed more or less in place and ridge interaction was related to the now-subducted Resurrection plate; or 2) the Chugach-Prince William terrane formed far to the south, was intruded by near-trench igneous rocks near a latitude of 48-49Â°N, and was subsequently translated along the continental margin to Alaska by strike slip faults similar to the San Andreas fault in California. The possible formation of the Chugach-Prince William terrane far to the south and subsequent translation along the continental margin is a defining event in western North American tectonics and makes testable predictions for the origin and thermal evolution of these rocks. We use geochronology, stratigraphy, petrology, structural geology, and geophysics to unravel the source region of this accretionary complex and subsequent thermal history. Together, these data are yielding important constraints on the accretion and translation history of the Chugach-Prince William terrane and has implications for the history of flanking basins such as the hydrocarbon-rich Cook Inlet basin.

This research directly addresses several key problems in North American tectonics related to terrane formation, translation, accretion, and basin formation, and is helping advance geochronologic methods used for tracking the origin and thermal evolution of sedimentary rocks. The results from this work are providing a better tectonic framework for understanding the timing and nature of basin formation (including hydrocarbon-rich strata), and the timing and extent of precious metals deposits (gold) associated with intrusive rocks. This project also has a strong educational component aimed at increasing the number of students in the geoscience pipeline and ultimately the workforce, and our effort is partly focused on recruiting students under-represented in the Geosciences. We are involved in the direct training, mentoring, and assessment of undergraduate students through the Keck Geology Consortium. Students are recruited, and assessed through the existing framework of the Consortium and this effort includes involvement of 30% of the students from non-Keck schools. There is a strong commitment to increasing the number of under-represented students in the Geoscience pipeline (this group includes African American, Hispanic, and Native American) and the new diversity initiative at the Keck Geology Consortium guarantees greater participation by this cohort. The Keck Consortium is dramatically increasing the number of under-represented student participation by several strategies including internal recruitment and external partners. The Keck Geology Consortium plays a leading role in the research training of promising students, and the majority of these students pursue a MSc and/or PhD in the geosciences. Thus the Consortium supplies the geoscience pipeline with bright, talented, well-trained students and many become leaders in the field. It is well known that research active faculty provide a successful and productive learning environment, and that student research at the undergraduate level provides students with the motivation, capability, and preparation for graduate school that typically leads to a productive career in the geosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. Our research focused on the Upper Cretaceous to Eocene strata of the Chugach-Prince William terrane, one of the largest accretionary complex in the world that extends for >2000 kilometers along the southern Alaska margin.  By dating the mineral zircon in these sedimentary rocks, we show that turbidites (sandstone and shale) of the Chugach-Prince William (CPW) terrane were deposited over a relatively short period of time (between 65 and 50 million years ago) and at low latitudes, perhaps as far south as southern California and then translated north to Alaska where we find them today.  We also show that the accretionary complex was intruded by granite plutons, and then the rocks cooled in a distinctive pattern related to tectonic activity.  Major findings include:

1. CPW turbidites as an accretionary terrane.  Turbidites of the Chugach and Orca Group are one lithotectonic assemblage that has remarkable homeogenity in zircon provenance across nearly 3000 km that evolved, but did not change fundamentally over time. Many of the turbidites from the Chugach Prince William terrane are younger (Paleocene) than previously reported (Cretaceous).

 2. Ophiolites in Prince William terrane.  The Resurrection Peninsula and Knight Island Ophiolites occur only in the Prince William terrane, and they are interbedded with Paleocene sediments, and are partially derived from those sediments suggesting an upper plate setting related to oblique transtension.

 3. Sanak-Baranof belt plutonism.  Crystallization ages of the Sanak-Baranof plutons using U/Pb zircon dating strengthen the case for the time transgressive nature of the plutonism from Sanak Island in the west to eastern Prince William Sound.  From eastern Prince William Sound to Baranof Island, the story is more complicated with magmatism recording crystallizations ages of 54-47 Ma. Hf isotopes suggest a temporal link to wedge assimilation because 56-53 Ma rocks have the most evolved signal.

 4. Age and extent of Orca Group. The volume of turbidites deposited from ~60-52 Ma is large, and these rocks were deposited, buried, and intruded by plutons of the Sanak-Baranof belt over a short period of time as evidenced by pluton crystallization ages that are indistinguishable (within error) of the maximum depositional ages of the turbidites they intrude.

 5. Precambrian zircons show large-scale terrane translation. There are differences in the detrital Precambrian zircons across the CPW belt.  Precambrian grains in most of the belt have a mix of grain ages typical of Northern Laurentian with juvenile and evolved Hf isotope signatures. Precambrian zircon ages in the Yakutat block are similar to Yavapai-Mazatzal zircon ages (peaks at ~1380 and ~1710) and have juvenile Hf isotope signatures distinctive of southern Laurentia, which is now exposed only in the SW United States.

 6. Several Stratigraphic correlations between CPW and Yakutat are incorrect.  The mélange sub-terrane of the Chugach is older and shows no continuity to the younger turbidites, and the mélange of the Yakutat Group is not correlative to other mélanges in the Chugach terrane, and contains elements as young as Paleocene. The Yakutat Group turbidites do not correlate to the CPW, and has a provenance that bears a strong similarity to the Nanaimo Group and the Western Mélange Belt in the Pacific Northwest, and the Schists of Southern California.

 Broader Impacts. This research project also helped advance the geosciences in terms of data, techniques, and human resources:

 1.  Dense sampling detrital zircon data set.  Compilation of a large data set of detrital zircon U/Pb ages (n=15,300 from 90 samples) and Hf isotope data (n=821 from 21 samples) for the CPW will allow geologists to test various models for the tectonic evolution of the North American Cordilleran.

 2. Radiation damage as a thermochronometer. Using radiation damage in Precambrian zircon as measured by change in SiO4 bond lengths using Raman spectroscopy to help constrain the metamorphic history of detrital zircon.

 3. Refinement of zircon fission track dating on grains with radiation damage. Low-temperature thermal events can be dated using annealing of fission tracks in high-damage zircon, so detrital zircons suites with a heterogeneity of damage show full annealing of high damage grains in a temperature range of 180-250° C.

 4. Framework for Economic deposits. The geologic framework for terrane formation and coast parallel translation is crucial for understanding the disposition of economic deposits in this belt of rocks. These economic deposits include 1) hydrocarbon-bearing strata on Yakutat and between the CPW and the continental framework? and 2) lode-gold deposits on the Kenai-Chugach mountains that are related to Sanak Baranof plutons.

 5. Student mentoring and training in Cordilleran science.  Mentoring 29 undergraduate researchers and giving them training in the complexity of doing field-based research in Alaska. Improved mentoring strategies for undergraduate researchers in the Geosciences with a focus on understanding Cordilleran tectonics, modern geochronology, and inter-related team research that involves scaffolding using reading and writing exercises.
